[1mุงููุตู ุงูุซุงูู: ุงูุชูุณูู [0m

(1) 

Khizar Hayar Tiwana to Major Short, 15 August 1947, Short Papers, OIOC (MSS. Eur. 189/19). 

(2) 

There is a massive literature on partition, which includes: (1) memoirs by key civil servants and military officials who served in 
the government at the time; (2) biographies of the important politicians involved in the negotiationsโNehru, Gandhi, Jinnah, 
Patel, Mountbatten, etc.โ(3) regional studies of partition in the Punjab and in Bengal; and (4) wider analytical overviews. To 
this must be added the volumes of original documents published both in England (the Transfer of Power project) and in India (the 
Toward Freedom Project plus the published correspondence of Nehru, Patel, Gandhi, and others). A fine recent overview, citing much 
of the relevant literature, is Sucheta Mahajan, [3mIndependence and Partition: The Erosion of Colonial Power in India [0m(New Delhi: 
Sage, 2000). An earlier work representing most of the competing points of view is C. H. Philips and Mary Doreen Wainwright, eds., [3m
The Partition of India: Policies and Perspectives [0m(London: George Allen and Unwin, 1970). 

(3) 

See the revealing portrait in the memoir of Jinnahโs former junior, M. C. Chagla, [3mRoses in December: An Autobiography [0m(1973, 
reprint Bombay: Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan, 1994), ch. 5. 

(4) 

Lord Birkenhead to Lord Reading, quoted in John Grigg, โMyths about the Approach to Indian Independence,โ in Wm. Roger Louis, ed., [3m
More Adventures with Britannia: Personalites, Politics, and Culture in Britain [0m(Austin: University of Texas Press, 1998), p. 211. 

(5) 

See Khalid bin Sayeed, [3mPakistan: The Formative Phase, 1857โ1948. [0m2nd ed. (Karachi: Oxford University Press, 1969), especially ch. 
6. Two magisterial treatments if Muslim consolidation during late colonial rule are C. S. Venkatachar, โ1937โ1947 in Retrospect: A 
Civil Servantโs View,โ in Philips and Wainwright, [3mThe Partition of India; [0mand Hamza Alavi, โMisreading Partition Road Signs,โ [3m
Economic and Political Weekly, [0m2โ9 November 2002. 

(6) 

Kenneth O. Morgan, [3mLabour in Power, 1945โ1951 [0m(Oxford: Clarendon, 1984), p. 221. 

(7) 

โThe Pakistan Nettle,โ in Moon Papers, OIOC (MSS. Eur. F. 230/39).

โThe 1946 Punjab Election,โ [3mModern Asian Studies, [0mVol. 14, No. I, 1980.

(7) 

There have been some fine studies of individual princely states, and of British policy toward the maharajas. However, no one since 
Menon has attempted an analytical overview of the demise of the princely order, with its (often profound) implications for the 
history of independent India. See V. P. Menon, [3mThe Story of the Integration of the Indian States [0m(New York: Macmillan, 1956).

(1) 

Donald F. Ebright, [3mFree India: The First Five YearsโAn Account of the 1947 Riots, Refugees, Relief, and Rehabilitation [0m(Nashville, 
Tenn.: Parthenon, 1954), pp. 46-47, 62-63, etc.

(4) 

This is section is principally based on M. S. Randhawa, [3mOut of the Ashes: An Account of the Rehabilitation of Refugees from West 
Punjab in Rural Areas of East Punjab [0m(Bombay: Author, 1954); and Gyanesh Kudaisya, โThe Demographic Upheaval of Partition: 
Refugees and Agricultural Resettlement in India, 1946-1947,โ [3mSouth Asia, [0mVol. 18, No. 1, 1995. Of the roughly 2.5 million farmers 
who came from West Punjab, about 80% were resettled in East Punjab. Others were given land in the Ganganagar area of the former 
Bikaner state, and in the Terai regions of Uttar Pradesh. In both places there are now flourishing communities of Sikh farmers. 

(5) 

Ian Stephen, โA Day in Qadian,โ [3mStatesman, [0m9 January 1949. Mohammad Zafrullah Khan, Pakistanโs eloquent spokesman in the UN on the 
Kashmir question, was an Ahmadiya. So was the physicist Abdus Salam, the only Pakistani to be awarded a Nobel Prize. In the 1980s, 
under the regime of General Zia-ul-Haq, the Ahmadiyas were declared heretics (for their belief in a living Prophet), and they have 
since faced discrimination and persecution.

See L. C. Jain, [3mThe City of Hope: The Faridabad Story [0m(New Delhi: Concept, 1998), which also describes the corrosion of the 
cooperative spirit by the bureaucracy. See also โExperiments in Living: FaridabadโNilokheriโEtawah,โ [3mTimes of India, [0m14 February 
1952.

(3) 

The [3mAutobiography [0mwas Nehruโs second book-length work. The first, whose title [3m(Glimpses of World History) [0mis testimony to his 
global outlook, was written initially as a series of letters to his daughter from jail. His third major book was published in 
1946; its title is also revealingโit was called [3mThe Discovery of India [0m, suggesting that perhaps this man was an internationalist 
well before he became a patriot, that he had discovered the world before he had discovered India.

an atomic war between the superpowers. When Nehru said he dreaded the prospect, Mao answered that he welcomed it, because while 
western imperialism would be destroyed the more populous socialist bloc would still have some men standing; these would then 
reproduce themselves, and in time โthe whole world would become socialist.โ See Stuart Schram, [3mMao Tse-tung [0m(Harmondsworth:

(19) 

Mahalanohis wrote he was โin favour of seeking the help of both USA and USSR (and of UK and other countries) in developing the 
industrial production of Indiaโ (letrer of 7 July 1954, in Pitamhar Pant Papers). He was in this respect genuinely non-partisan. 
In the years to come, his ISI was host to top economists from both sides of the Iron CurtainโSimon Kuznets, Oskar Lange, Charles 
Bettelheim, Jan Tinbergen, and many others. For details, see Rudra, [3mPrasanta Chandra Mahalanobis, [0mch. 14.

minister changed the title of the bill from the Hindu Marriage and Divorce Bill to the Hindu Marriage Bill. This was done to put 
the accent โnot on the dissolution of marriageโ but on the โmaintenance of marriage [which] is more importantโ ( [3mLok Sabha 
Debates, [0m26 April 1955). The change, needless to say, was cosmetic.

makes a discrimination in favour of the Muslims who may marry four wives under the Shariat law and not incur any of the offences 
under this Actโ ( [3mRajya Sabha Debates, [0m6 December 1954).

(1)

the Naga Hills, W. G. Archer, she had interviewed a cross section of the NNC membership and also collected their journal. She was 
herself to become, in later years, an authority on British art in India.

(1) 

[3mReport on the Second General Elections in India. 1957 [0m(New Delhi: Election Commission, 1958). 

(2) 

Feroze Gandhi was also from the Nehrusโ hometown, Allahabad. A Parsi by faith, he at first spelled his surname โGhandy.โ However, 
after he joined the national movement as a young man, he changed the spelling to bring it in line with that of Mahatma Gandhi. The 
amended surname proved to be of incalculable significance to his wife, because most foreigners, and not a few Indians, assumed 
that she was in some way related to the Mahatma.

See Katherine Frank, [3mIndira: A Life of Indira Nehru Gandhi [0m(London: Harper-Collins, 2001), pp. 240-241.

(24) 

Steven A. Hoffman, [3mIndia and the China Crisis [0m(Delhi: Oxford University Press, 1990), pp. 67, 73, 82-83, etc. The origins and 
trajectory of the India- China dispute are, as one can imagine, the subject of a huge and very motivated literature. On the one 
side are various self-serving memoirs by Indian generals and officials, which seek to blame China for โbetrayingโ Indiaโs trust. 
These are collectively answered by Neville Maxwellโs [3mIndiaโs China War [0m, a well documented book that, however, sees everything, 
big and small, from the Chinese point of view. Hoffmanโs is an admirably detached and comprehensive account of the dispute, 
perhaps the best there is.

Steven Hoffman, [3mIndia and the China Crisis, [0mpp. 86-87, explains that Chouโs offer to โbarterโ could not be acceptable to India 
because โit was being asked to accept the clandestine and forceful seizure of parts of its territory [in the west], in return for 
a worthless assurance that another part of the frontier [in the east] would not be menaced.โ

jingoism. To take revenge on innocent shopkeepers was deeply wrong-headed, for โwe should always distinguish between governmental 
action and the people as a whole.โ

(6) 

There was also a letter, too crazy, perhaps, to quote in the text, which urged a cheaper method of disposing of the Chinese threat 
than arming the Indians. S. B. Crowe of Sanford, Florida, recommended that the Americans drop boxes of atomic waste, each with an 
explosive charge, on the Chinese side of the Himalaya. The communists would be told of this, so that they would โstay out of Tibet 
and India.โ However, โif Mao wishes to conduct an experiment in genetics and send 150 million through this radiation hazard, it 
would be an interesting experiment.โ Estimating that this would save the American taxpayer โabout a billion dollars,โ Mr. Crowe 
signed off as follows: โYours for more economy in Government. The barrel isnโt bottomless, inspite of Mr. Keynes and his 
theories.โ

(29) 

Telegram dated 29 April 1964, in Subject File No. 92, C. Rajagopalachari Papers, Fourth Instalment, NMML. 

(30) 

Ibid., letter of 29 April 1964. As some other letters in this file show, most members of the Swatantra party opposed Masani and 
Rajaji in their support of the talks between Nehru and Abdullah. K. M. Munshi said that Sheikh Abdullah should be put back in 
jail. Dahyabhai Patel (son of Vallabhbhai Patel) said that the only solution to the problem of Kashmir was to settle the Valley 
with Hindu refugees from East Pakistan.

Ibid., Abdullah to Minoo Masani, 16 April 1964.

Ibid., Shastri to Rajaji, 4 May 1964.

Instalment, NMML. 

(35) 

HT, 23 May 1964. 

(36) 

Y. D. Gundevia to V. K. T. Chari (attorney-general, Madras), 13 May 1964, Subject File No. 4, y. D. Gundevia Papers, NMML. A 
confederation as a solution to the Kashmir problem was apparently first proposed by the journalist Arthur Moore as early as 
January 1948. Moore believed that โIndia, Pakistan and Kashmir should become a federated commonwealth state, with common foreign 
affairs, common defence, and such finance as concerned these subjects, but otherwise all three to be self-governing States.โ He 
spoke about it to Mahatma Gandhi, and later also appears to have broached the topic with the prime minister. Moore also wrote 
about it in a volume of tributes on Nehruโs seventieth birthday, calling this issue the โgreatest test for Nehruโs statesmanship โฆ 
[for] there will never be satisfactory relations between India and Pakistan till the Kashmir issue is settled.โ See Arthur Moore, 
โMy Friendโs Son,โ in Rafiq Zakaria, ed., [3mA Study of Nehru, [0m2nd ed. (Bombay: Times of India Press, 1960; originally published 
1959), especially pp. 175-176. It seems very likely, considering where Mooreโs article appeared, that Nehru had read this essay. 

(37) 

Letter of 20 May 1964, in Subject File No. 92, C. Rajagopalachari Papers, Fourth Instalment, NMML. In Parliament, Masani was one 
of the fiercest critics of the prime minister. But, like his mentor Rajaji, he saw that in progress on Kashmir lay the future of 
the subcontinent. On this subject at least he was willing to support Nehru. 

(38) 

HT, 25 May 1964. Unless otherwise indicated, the rest of this section is based on HT, 25 to 30 May 1964.

[3mDawn, [0mquoted in HT, 27 May 1964. (Emphasis added.)

Gandhi, and Tihar Jail,โ [3mPUCL Bulletin, [0mVol. 5, No. 8, August 1985. Dayal and Bose, as well as Mehta, write that Jagmohanโs 
determination to clear Turkman Gate was in part motivated by the fact that the residents were Muslimsโhe saw them, apparently, as 
Pakistani fifth columnists. Jagmohanโs own account of the incident is in [3mIsland of Truth, [0mpp. 144โ149.

(57) 

This account is based on my own interactions with these groups over the past three decades. Unfortunately, there is no history of 
the civil liberties movement in modern India, and there are no studies of its most important groupsโsuch as the Peopleโs Union for 
Civil Liberties and the Peopleโs Union for Democratic Rights, both based in Delhi; the pioneering Association for the Protection 
of Democratic Rights, based in Calcutta; the Committee for the Protection of Democratic Rights, based in Bombay; and the Andhra 
Pradesh Civil Liberties Committee, based in Hyderabad. Dr. Sitarama Kakarala of the National Law School in Bangalore is currently 
completing a book on the last-named group.

(38) 

Sonia Jabbar, โBlood Soil: Chittisinghpora and After,โ in Urvashi Butalia, ed., [3mSpeaking Peace: Womenโs Voices from Kashmir [0m(New 
Delhi: Kali for Women, 2002), p p. 226f. 

(39) 

There has been some dispute about the agents of the Chittisinghpora massacre. For the argument that the killers were recruited by 
Indian intelligence, which then sought to pin the blame on Pakistan, see Pankaj Mishra, [3mTemptations of the West: How to be Modern 
in India, Pakistan and Beyond [0m(London: Picador, 2006), pp. 197ff. For the alternative point of view, namely, that the killers were 
militants who came in from Pakistan, see Praveen Swami, โIron Veils: Reporting Sub-Continental Warfare in India,โ in Nalini Rajan, 
ed., [3mPractising Journalism: Values, Constraints, Implications [0m(New Delhi: Sage, 2005). My own assessment, that these were most 
likely freelancers from across the border, is guided, among other things, by a crucial piece of evidence provided by the 
survivors. This is that the killers spoke both Punjabi and Urdu. Now Urdu is spoken by many Muslims in the Indian State of Uttar 
Pradesh who, however, do not speak any Punjabi. And the only Punjabis who speak Urdu in the Indian state of Punjab would have had 
their schooling in that language before partition. They would now be at least seventy years of age, and presumably in no position 
to trek over high hills to effect a mass murder. On the other hand, there are millions of able-bodied young men in the Pakistan 
Punjab who speak both their mother tongue and the national language, Urdu. As this book must have made quite clear by now, the 
Indian state has been guilty of many criminal acts in Jammu and Kashmir. But the massacre of the Sikhs in Chittisinghpora does not 
appear to be among them.

See Atal Behari Vajpayee, โMusings from Kumarakom,โ [3mHindu, [0m2 January 2001.
